bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Louise Young Kean, October 5, 1906

div1.p: Kean writes his first letter home to his wife after his arrival in Cuba. He describes where he is living and how he has set up his office, as well as sends greetings from many of their acquaintances living in Cuba. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Louise Young Kean, October 5, 1906
div1.p:
We arrived yesterday morning after a
smooth trip in the night from Key West and
were met by a Launch with the indispensable
Steinhart and Capts Butt & Cole - and Major
Runcie who took Baker off to his house.
Steinhard took possession of Capt McIntyre
& me & installed us at the Inglaterra in a
bridal chamber where Mac is installed and
a second room which contains my bed &
the bath tub! I let McIntyre use my tub & he
lets me look out of his front window & so
the modus vivendi is established. This elegance
mind you is not at our own expense for we
for the present are to have either actual ex-
penses or a per diem to cover them - thank
God. So bankrupcy is not added to the
grief of parting from the dearest of wives.
I breakfasted with the Laine's & reported to
the Secy who gave me a very complimentary
order to Dr Finlay to act as his “aide”
in the same sense that Slocum was General
Alejandro Rodriguez' assistant. It is to me
a very satisfactory relation as I am very fond
of the old Doctor who is really a dear old
man tho. I cannot understand more than
half of what he tells me. I dined with Ladd
Crewdon & Mr Vaughan at the Dos Hermanos
and Vaughan spend most of dinner send-
ing nice messages to you. He asked if you
still looked like you were fifteen - and
Ladd hastened to assure him that you did
Mrs Vaughan is in the states & he is going up
for her tomorrow. He said they were going
to ask you to come back with them. I told
him he had better not as you would
certainly take him up. We then rode up
& down the Prado & the malecon in O's
beautiful French auto for a while, stopped
at the Miraman got a drink & chatted
with the gang that soon gathered. - Baker
Capt. Shirley & Horten & Mr Greenwood - & then
I strolled up the Prado to the Inglaterra
& to bed after chatting in the portico with Mr.
Davis of the N. Y. Times until I got cool.
3.
I have not told you half the things I did or
rather the people I saw, all the Beneficencia
people & Dick Bullard & Major Neville of the
Marines who is camped at Columbia Bks &
little Posy. All wanted to be remembered to
you and to know if you were coming down.
This morning I went to Las Animas & to the
Palace. I have secured Peña (you remember
Dr Peña) to be my interpreter & assistant.
He is all the special office force I will have
at present. I suppose I can use a Cuban
typewriter from the immense office force
of the Junta Superior de Sanidad if I
need one. Do you know in looking
around for a place to put my desk I
discovered that my old office was va-
cant and I am now installed there
with the soft east wind blowing on me
from across the bay.

After Breakfast - I have unpacked my blanket
roll and got out some good North American pens
instead of these sharp Cuban things that I never
could write with. I have also Peña installed in
4
a desk behind me and am beginning to
feel really at home. Peña puzzled me just
now by asking for my official title. I
told him that he would have to give me time
to make up one & have it approved.
There are only three mails a week now
which is the reason why you will have
quite a delay in getting this my first letter
written from Cuba. They go Tuesday Thursday
& Saturday. I will write to the Chief by this
mail also but you must go down to
see him and exchange news as I
am subject to so many interruptions
that I fear his letter will be short
I will send him a copy of the Secy's
letter to Dr Finlay fixing my status for
the present. Which I will ask him to
show you & give you a copy of
Goodbye dear heart, I miss you constantly
and will I know do so more and more.
Give my love to the children & to Carrie if she
has come. I will send Martha & Bob some
postals soon. These cigar bands were given me by
5
Mr Merchant the vice President of Mr
Vaughans bank, the Banco Nacional de
Cuba - you see they have his initials in
them being made to order.

I hope tomorrow boat will bring a letter
from you. You have received by cable
sent by McIntyre the news of my safe
arrival.

I had a long talk with Dr Guiteras this
morning at Las Animas and he invited
me to come & live with him there. I may
do so for a while as his family is away
but as long as McIntyre is at the Ingla-
terra I will probably stay there with him
but his stay will I think be short
Ladd too says he is going home soon.
The Secy will go the middle of the month
when Magoon is safely installed.
